newsitem.title: BURUNDI: Burundi soldiers accused of another massacre.
newsitem.headline: Burundi soldiers accused of another massacre.

text.p: Soldiers in Burundi massacred at least 83 civilians in a single operation last Sunday night, witnesses and other sources alleged on Friday.
The victims, believed to be from the Hutu majority, were attacked late on January 5 near Rutegama in Muramvya province about 65 km (40 miles) from the capital, Bujumbura, they said.
"The soldiers circled the hillsides of Kabuguzo and Kinyoni...and killed almost everyone," one witness said.
The bodies of 75 people had been buried in a mass grave and eight more were thrown into the nearby Kaniga river, the sources said.
The sources refused to be quoted by name, fearing reprisals.
"I have not heard anything about this incident," Jean-Luc Ndizeye, spokesman for Major Pierre Buyoya, Burundi's military leader, told Reuters in Nairobi by telephone.
Burundi's 25,000-strong army is overwhelmingly drawn from the Tutsi minority and is frequently accused by human rights organisation of committing massacres against Hutus.

Some of the most recent victims are former refugees, forced from their camps in neighbouring eastern Zaire late last year because of a rebellion. They returned to Burundi reluctantly and hundreds have been killed, relief workers say.

Buyoya was installed by the army last July after a coup against the previous coalition government. In protest against the coup, regional states imposed economic and political sanctions but Burundi is managing to subvert most of them, diplomats say.
The army routinely denies committing massacres and blames Hutu rebels for atrocities that have cost at least 150,000 lives in the past three years.
But the defence ministry ordered the arrest of an army officer last month after his unit was blamed for the deaths of 79 civilians in Rumonga commune.
